PostValue.explanation: For the EA/rationalist community this piece is highly important because it interrogates load‑bearing foundations (expected‑value decision‑making, longtermist assumptions, and the normative status of moral claims) and therefore has practical implications for cause prioritisation, robustness heuristics, risk policy and interest in moral enhancement — if its conclusions hold, many EA strategies would need significant rethinking. For general humanity it is of moderate interest: the arguments bear on broad worldview and future policy debates (e.g. bio/neuro tech, AI governance, and secular ethics), but they are largely philosophical and indirect in their short‑term practical impact for most people.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Overstates the "collapse" and under‑engages with major counterarguments. The post frames cluelessness, infinitarian problems and anti‑realism as a near‑terminal collapse of the moral project, but it gives short shrift to well‑known responses (robust decision rules, bounded utility moves, sceptical priors, constructivist or convergence accounts) and to the practical degree of the worry. Actionable fix: soften absolutist language, add a concise paragraph for each major objection summarising the strongest, succinct rebuttals or mitigations and explain why those rebuttals may or may not be sufficient for EA practice. This will prevent the piece from reading as a one‑sided demolition and make its recommendations more credible.

2) The moral bioenhancement discussion is speculative and underplays ethical, political and evidential constraints. It moves quickly from lab findings (oxytocin, TMS) to broad proposals without engaging governance, consent, distributional effects, perverse incentives, or the very real risk of authoritarian misuse. Actionable fix: reframe this section as a cautious research agenda rather than an endorsement; explicitly discuss autonomy, consent and governance mechanisms (voluntary programmes, regulatory oversight, international norms), and demand higher evidential standards before implying deployment. Adding one or two concrete, realistic use‑cases (with downsides) would ground the argument.

3) Practical recommendations for EA are too high‑level to be useful under the paper's sceptical premises. If the post's point is to change EA practice in light of these worries, readers need concrete heuristics and examples (not just "be humble" and "prioritise robustness"). Actionable fix: convert the conclusion into a short, actionable checklist: e.g. prioritise robustness to model error, invest X% in forecasting and meta‑research, apply caps or probability floors in EV calculations, prefer interventions with clear cancellation‑resistance, and run iterative pilots with pre‑registered evaluation. Give one or two brief case studies showing how these heuristics alter decisions (eg. how to compare bednets vs long‑term policy work under cluelessness).
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets three central weaknesses that would materially improve the post: (1) it correctly flags the one‑sided tone and failure to engage prominent rebuttals (robust decision rules, bounded‑utility moves, constructivist/convergence accounts), which risks making the piece read polemical rather than persuasive; (2) it calls out the speculative leap in the moral bioenhancement section and the lack of discussion of autonomy, governance and misuse — an own‑goal that could embarrass the author if noticed; and (3) it requests concrete, actionable heuristics rather than high‑level exhortations, which is exactly what readers need under the paper’s sceptical premises. These are critical, practical fixes that can be implemented without massively lengthening the post. Minor gaps remain (e.g. it doesn’t suggest specific short rebuttal paragraphs or exact checklist items), but overall the feedback would substantially raise the piece’s credibility and usefulness.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I could not find a widely recognized EA/rationalist presence or major public profile for an 'Aaron Clarke' under that name. The name is common and could be a private author, minor online figure, or a pseudonym. If you provide links, works, or more context I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Well-structured and generally easy to follow: clear sectioning, helpful examples (Lenman, Bostrom, Pascal’s Mugging), and concrete takeaways for EA. Argumentation is coherent and mostly compelling, moving from problems (cluelessness, infinities, evolutionary accounts) to practical implications. Main weaknesses are length and some repetition, occasional dense technical jargon (e.g. measure problem, EDR) that assumes philosophical background, and a few normative leaps in the more speculative sections (moral bioenhancement, AI interventions). Overall readable for an EA audience but could be tightened for broader accessibility.

PostNovelty.explanation: Most of the post’s material is a synthesis of well‑known debates in ethics, decision theory and moral psychology (cluelessness, Bostrom’s infinitarian problems, Pascal’s Mugging, evolutionary accounts of morality, moral bioenhancement, and anti‑realist arguments) that EA readers are already familiar with, so it is only slightly novel as a framing. For the general educated public the particular combination and application of these threads to Effective Altruism (especially linking infinite ethics, moral engineering and epistemic humility) is moderately novel but not highly original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is logically structured, engages key philosophical objections (cluelessness, infinitarian problems, moral anti‑realism), and situates empirical literature on the evolutionary origins of morality and some neuroscience findings. It acknowledges counterarguments and draws plausible implications for EA, emphasising epistemic humility and robustness. Weaknesses: A number of moves are rhetorical or speculative (e.g. practical implications of cosmological infinity, feasibility and safety of large‑scale moral bioenhancement) and some empirical claims are overgeneralised from limited lab results (oxytocin, TMS, SSRIs). The evidence base is solid for the evolutionary account and the philosophical sources cited, but thinner for concrete policy prescriptions and futuristic interventions. Overall, the thesis is well argued and fairly supported, but some claims rely on contested or nascent evidence and would benefit from more cautious qualification.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes:
Overall assessment: the post accurately summarises the main academic debates and cites the right literature — the epistemic ‘cluelessness’ challenge (Lenman; Greaves), infinitarian problems and Pascal’s Mugging (Bostrom), the evolutionary/cultural account of morality (Curry; Tomasello), and active research into neuro- and bio‑interventions for moral behaviour (Persson & Savulescu; oxytocin/serotonin/TMS studies). Those substantive claims are supported by peer‑reviewed work. ([onlinelibrary.wiley.com](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1088-4963.2000.00342.x?utm_source=openai), [philarchive.org](https://philarchive.org/rec/GREC-38?utm_source=openai), [fhi.ox.ac.uk](https://www.fhi.ox.ac.uk/publications/bostrom-n-2011-infinite-ethics-analysis-and-metaphysics-10-9-59/?utm_source=openai), [ora.ox.ac.uk](https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid%3A8dd8d82d-3829-4857-bcf4-eebf196d11be?utm_source=openai), [annualreviews.org](https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-psych-113011-143812?utm_source=openai))

Major strengths: (1) The post correctly identifies key scholarly sources and accurately represents the broad contours of those arguments (epistemic uncertainty about far‑future consequences; the technical problems infinites create for aggregative consequentialism; empirical evidence that moral psychology is shaped by evolved and cultural factors; experimental evidence that neuromodulators and brain stimulation can change moral judgement). ([philarchive.org](https://philarchive.org/rec/GREC-38?utm_source=openai), [fhi.ox.ac.uk](https://www.fhi.ox.ac.uk/publications/bostrom-n-2011-infinite-ethics-analysis-and-metaphysics-10-9-59/?utm_source=openai), [ora.ox.ac.uk](https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid%3A8dd8d82d-3829-4857-bcf4-eebf196d11be?utm_source=openai), [pnas.org](https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.0914826107?utm_source=openai))

Major caveats / weaknesses: (a) Some empirical statements are presented with stronger certainty than the evidence warrants — e.g., oxytocin’s effects are context‑dependent and often increase in‑group favouritism rather than universal empathy (Kosfeld et al.; De Dreu et al.). SSRIs/serotonergic effects on harm‑aversion are real but nuanced and moderated by trait differences. TMS alters aspects of moral judgement in lab tasks, but this does not straightforwardly imply controllable, generalisable “moral enhancement” in real‑world settings. ([science.org](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.1189047?utm_source=openai), [pnas.org](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1015316108?utm_source=openai), [pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2951447/?utm_source=openai)) (b) The claims about genetic editing / CRISPR to select “morality” or specific personality traits are speculative: large GWAS identify tiny, highly polygenic effects and polygenic prediction/portability limits are substantial; safe, reliable heritable editing of complex behavioural traits is not currently feasible. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6393768/?utm_source=openai)) (c) Cosmology: current data (Planck) are consistent with spatial flatness (so infinite models remain possible), but whether space is actually infinite is an unsettled empirical question — Bostrom’s infinitarian challenge is philosophically important but rests on an empirical hypothesis that is not settled. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.06209?utm_source=openai), [fhi.ox.ac.uk](https://www.fhi.ox.ac.uk/bostrom-n-%C2%93infinite-ethics%C2%94-in-analysis-and-metaphysics-vol-10-2011-pp-9-59/?utm_source=openai))

Overall verdict: most of the post’s empirical claims are well‑grounded in the literature (so it deserves a “well‑supported” rating), but several speculative or policy‑oriented leaps (large‑scale moral biological/genetic engineering; definitive claims about an actually infinite universe) are presented with insufficient hedging. That lowers the score slightly from ‘very strongly validated’ to 7/10.

Tomasello M. & Vaish A., "Origins of Human Cooperation and Morality" (Annual Review of Psychology, 2013).
Persson I. & Savulescu J., "The Duty to be Morally Enhanced" (Topoi, 2019/2017 article).
Kosfeld M. et al., "Oxytocin increases trust in humans" (Nature, 2005) and De Dreu C.K.W. et al., "Oxytocin promotes parochial altruism / ethnocentrism" (Science/PNAS, 2010/2011).
Crockett M.J. et al., "Serotonin selectively influences moral judgment and behavior" (PNAS, 2010).

Lee J.J. et al., "Gene discovery and polygenic prediction from a 1.1-million-person GWAS of educational attainment" (Nature Genetics, 2018) and Mostafavi H. et al., "Variable prediction accuracy of polygenic scores within an ancestry group" (eLife, 2020) — cited to show limits of behavioural genetic prediction.
Planck Collaboration, "Planck 2018 results. VI. Cosmological parameters" (2018) — cited for curvature/flatness constraints.
Sharon Street, "A Darwinian dilemma for realist theories of value" (Philosophical Studies, 2006).
Derek Parfit, "On What Matters" (2011) and William MacAskill, "What We Owe the Future" (2022) — cited for the philosophical debate about moral realism and longtermism.
